panels.title: Vendor:$vendor Instance:$instance Scenario:$scenario Node:$node Activity:$activity K:$k Op:$op

panels.description:
This view shows the current cycle progress in terms of cycles values dispensed to threads and a count of those which have been fully processed.

__Dispatched cycles__ are those which have been allocated to activity threads to process. __Retired cycles__ are those which have not been retired or completed. 

The difference between the two represents work which is subscribed by activity threads but not yet complete.
panels.title: Cycles V:$vendor S:$scenario A:$activity

panels.description:
These two metrics show the 1-minute averaged ops per second for all ops (successes and errors) and succesful ops (no errors during execution) separately.

When there are no errors, these metrics should be the same. When there are errors, there will be a difference. In that case, you can look at the error metrics to learn more about what is happening.

By comparing these two metrics for any activity, you have a quick first-glance sanity check that your tests are configured properly and
that there are no serious configuration or resource issues. In addition, this is the primary throughput metric.
panels.title: Ops V:$vendor S:$scenario A:$activity

panels.description:
The tries distribution is an HDR histogram which represents how many times an operation was submitted. In a well balanced system, tries should be 1 across the board.

Every operation which is executed within NoSQLBench should have a `tries` metric. For example, with CQL, the number of times an operation is submitted before it is succesful is ideally 1. If you are overloading your target system, thus forcing resource contention, you may see operations timeout.


By default, NoSQLBench will try up to 10 times to submit operations before giving up and throwing an error for an operation.

The tries metric can be used as a low-noise indicator of system saturation. For example, if you are running a system marginally beyond its capacity, the tries for operations will go above 1 at the higher percentiles such as P99. If you increase the load even further, more retries will be needed and less work will be completed, thus showing higher retries at even lower percentiles, like P95, for example.

As such, you can use the tries metric as an indicator of relative saturation.
panels.title: Tries V:$vendor S:$scenario A:$activity

panels.description:
When an exception is caught and counted in a scenario, a specially named metric is emited which includes a simplified name of the error type.

Each of these metrics is created as needed in the NoSQLBench runtime.

These metrics are formated with a name pattern of `errorcounts.NAME` where NAME is the simple name of the exception class which was caught during the operation. For example, For an activity named `foo``, you would expect an exception named `FooTimeoutException` to be shown with a metric name of ... `foo.errorcounts.FooTimeoutException`
panels.title: Errors V:$vendor S:$scenario A:$activity

targets.expr: threads{workload=~"$workload", activity=~"$activity", instance=~"$instance", session=~"$session", scenario=~"$scenario", target=~"$target", container=~"$container"}

panels.description:
The service time distribution is an HDR histogram that represents the time elapsed from when an operation is submitted for execution to when its result has been received.

From the vantage point of the NoSQLBench runtime, this is a client-side metric. Thus, the service time captures the processing time that an application would see, including driver logic, wire time (transport), and server-side processing.

This metric does not include the waittime or the responsetime metrics. These metrics are only meaningful (and provided) when a `cyclerate=` is provided to an activity. When computing the responsetime metric, the servicetime is added to the waittime for a given operation.
panels.title: SvcTime V:$vendor S:$scenario A:$activity

panels.description:
The service time distribution is an HDR histogram that represents the time elapsed from when an operation is submitted for execution to when its result has been received.

From the vantage point of the NoSQLBench runtime, this is a client-side metric. Thus, the service time captures the processing time that an application would see, including driver logic, wire time (transport), and server-side processing.

This metric does not include the waittime or the responsetime metrics. These metrics are only meaningful (and provided) when a `cyclerate=` is provided to an activity. When computing the responsetime metric, the servicetime is added to the waittime for a given operation.
panels.title: SvcTime/1m V:$vendor S:$scenario A:$activity

panels.description: This panel shows the number of cycles remaining, pending, and complete for a given activity
panels.title: Progress V:$vendor S:$scenario A:$activity

panels.description:
This is a view of successful operations for a specific op:
- op: $op
- scenario: $scenario
- activity: $activity
panels.title: SUCCESSES for $op [$scenario $activity]

panels.description:
These two metrics show the 1-minute averaged ops per second for all ops (successes and errors) and succesful ops (no errors during execution) separately.

When there are no errors, these metrics should be the same. When there are errors, there will be a difference. In that case, you can look at the error metrics to learn more about what is happening.

By comparing these two metrics for any activity, you have a quick first-glance sanity check that your tests are configured properly and
that there are no serious configuration or resource issues. In addition, this is the primary throughput metric.
panels.title: ERRORS for $op [$scenario $activity]
